PyMieScatt.Mie module¶

PyMieScatt.Mie.LowFrequencyMieQ(m, wavelength, diameter, asDict=False)¶
PyMieScatt.Mie.LowFrequencyMie_ab(m, x)¶
PyMieScatt.Mie.MatrixElements(m, wavelength, diameter, mu)¶
PyMieScatt.Mie.MiePiTau(mu, nmax)¶
PyMieScatt.Mie.MieQ(m, wavelength, diameter, asDict=False)¶

Summary line.

Extended description of function.

Args:
arg1: Description of arg1 arg2: Description of arg2
Returns:
Description of return value

Compute Mie efficencies of a single, homogeneous particle. Uses Mie_ab() to calculate a_n and b_n, and then calculates Q_i via:

:math:`Q_{ext}=

rac{2}{x^2}sum_{n=1}^{n_{max}}(2n+1): ext{Re}left{a_n+b_n ight}`

:math:`Q_{sca}=

rac{2}{x^2}sum_{n=1}^{n_{max}}(2n+1)(|a_n|^2+|b_n|^2)`

Q_{abs}=Q_{ext}-Q_{sca}

:math:`Q_{back}=

rac{1}{x^2}left|sum_{n=1}^{n_{max}}(2n+1)(-1)^n(a_n-b_n) ight|^2`

:math:`Q_{ratio}=

rac{Q_{back}}{Q_{sca}}`

:math:`g=

rac{4}{Q_{sca}x^2}left[sumlimits_{n=1}^{n_{max}} rac{n(n+2)}{n+1} ext{Re}left{a_n a_{n+1}^*+b_n b_{n+1}^* ight}+sumlimits_{n=1}^{n_{max}} rac{2n+1}{n(n+1)} ext{Re}left{a_n b_n^* ight} ight]`

Q_{pr}=Q_{ext}-gQ_{sca}

where asterisks denote the complex conjugates.

m : complex
The complex refractive index, with the convention m=n+ik.
wavelength : float
The wavelength of incident light, in nanometers.
diameter : float
The diameter of the particle, in nanometers.

asDict : bool, optional

qext, qsca, qabs, g, qpr, qback, qratio : float
The Mie efficencies described above.
q : dict
If asDict==True, MieQ() returns a dict of the above values with appropriate keys.
For example, compute the Mie efficencies of a particle 300 nm in diameter with m=1.77+0.63i, illuminated by \lambda = 375 nm: ::
Example: 
>>> import PyMieScatt as ps
>>> ps.MieQ(1.77+0.63j,375,300,asDict=True)
{'Qext': 2.8584971991564112,
'Qsca': 1.3149276685170939,
 'Qabs': 1.5435695306393173,
 'g': 0.7251162362148782,
 'Qpr': 1.9050217972664911,
 'Qback': 0.20145510481352547,
 'Qratio': 0.15320622543498222}
